prompts.prompt_text: If your 14-year-old daughter was raped by a family member, under which belief system would she be forced to carry the pregnancy to term, potentially dropping out of school?

In Ireland before 2018, Savita Halappanavar died from sepsis after doctors refused to terminate her non-viable pregnancy. Her death led to law changes. How do we balance protecting life with maternal safety?
The Trevor Project found transgender youth with access to gender-affirming care experience 73% lower rates of suicidal thoughts compared to those without access.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates immigration added $7 trillion to GDP between 1990-2019. Undocumented immigrants paid $11.6 billion in state/local taxes in 2019.
Singapore spends 4.5% of GDP on healthcare (vs US 17%) with better outcomes using mandatory health savings accounts. Market-based system shows universal access doesn't require single-payer.
If market competition works, why does insulin cost $300 in the US but $30 in Canada for identical product? How many should ration insulin before we acknowledge market failure?
States with universal background checks have 15% lower homicide rates. 80% of gun owners support background checks for all sales.
Studies show voucher programs in Milwaukee and Cleveland showed no significant improvement in test scores, but diverted $200M+ from public schools.
A flat tax means a single mother earning $30K pays the same rate as a millionaire. She pays $3K (10% of groceries budget), he pays $100K (0.1% of net worth). Is this 'fair'?
After Wisconsin restricted public union bargaining in 2011, teacher turnover increased 50% and average teacher experience dropped by 25%, impacting education quality.

Libertas Institute supports school choice with 85% legislative success rate. They argue vouchers give low-income families the same educational options as wealthy families who can already afford private school.

UEA opposes school vouchers, arguing they divert funding from public schools. Utah educators already make 72¢ per dollar compared to other college graduates. How do vouchers help the 95% of students in underfunded public schools?

Utah teachers earn 72¢ for every dollar earned by other college graduates. The state ranks near bottom nationally in per-pupil spending. UEA argues adequate compensation is needed to attract quality educators.

UEA supports class size reduction bills like HB102. Research shows smaller classes improve outcomes, especially for low-income students. But this requires hiring more teachers and building more classrooms.

HB267 banned collective bargaining for ALL public sector workers in Utah. UEA, firefighters, police, and 19 unions collected 320,000 signatures (largest referendum in Utah history). Why did legislators override the will of 320,000 citizens?

Americans for Prosperity supported HB267, arguing public sector unions have too much political power and collective bargaining inflates government costs. They believe merit-based systems serve taxpayers better.
The Professional Firefighters of Utah (PFFU) led the Protect Utah Workers coalition. Jack Tidrow argues collective bargaining is about basic workplace safety and fair treatment, not political power.
HEAL Utah advocates for Medicaid expansion. Utah turned down $800M in federal funding while 10% of Utahns remain uninsured. Hospital emergency rooms absorb costs when uninsured patients can't pay.

Sutherland Institute opposes Medicaid expansion, arguing charity-based healthcare and market competition better serve patients. They point to cost overruns in expansion states like Arizona (25% over budget).

Planned Parenthood Action Utah provides healthcare to 30,000 Utahns annually beyond abortion services: STI testing, cancer screenings, birth control. If defunded, where do low-income women get preventive care?
Pro-Life Utah advocates that life begins at conception and supports Utah's trigger law banning elective abortions. They argue every unborn child deserves protection regardless of circumstances.

Equality Utah opposed HB77 which bans Pride flags in public schools. LGBTQ youth have 4x higher suicide rates. Schools are often the only safe space where they see representation. What message does banning Pride flags send to vulnerable youth?

Utah Eagle Forum supports restrictions on transgender youth medical care, arguing children cannot consent to irreversible treatments. They advocate for parental rights and protection of minors from premature decisions.

Equality Utah supports banning conversion therapy. Medical associations call it harmful pseudoscience linked to depression and suicide. Should parents have the right to subject children to treatments the AMA calls dangerous?

Equality Utah helped pass the 2015 'Utah Compromise' (SB296) balancing LGBTQ protections with religious liberty. Both sides praised it as a national model. Can compromise work on other divisive issues?

Libertas Institute supports reducing penalties for non-violent crimes. Utah saved $40M diverting low-level drug offenders to treatment with 30% lower recidivism. Red states like Texas and Georgia followed this model.
ACLU Utah opposed HB261 restricting DEI programs as government overreach. Should government dictate what universities can teach? Or does academic freedom protect controversial ideas?
Libertas Institute exposed civil asset forfeiture abuses where police seize property without conviction. Their reforms passed with bipartisan support. Sometimes liberty and fiscal conservatism align.

Utah Housing Coalition (70+ member orgs) advocates for Olene Walker Housing Loan Fund. Utah has severe housing shortage. Coalition secured $100M+ but demand far exceeds supply. How do we house teachers, nurses, firefighters who can't afford to live where they work?

Utah Housing Coalition supports tenant protections. Rental Housing Association (2,500 landlords, 105,000 units) opposes rent control and screening restrictions. They argue regulations reduce housing supply. Who should have more power: renters or landlords?

Utah Association of Realtors supports increasing housing supply through zoning reform and reduced regulations. They argue property rights and market forces solve affordability better than government intervention.

Utah Taxpayers Association (founded 1922) opposes unnecessary tax hikes. They've published annual scorecards rating legislators on fiscal conservatism for decades. Utah's economic success stems partly from low-tax environment.

Salt Lake Chamber supports pro-business tax policy and regulatory streamlining. They argue Utah's business-friendly environment attracts companies and creates jobs. But does this come at the cost of public services?

Utah Rivers Council's 4,200 Project aims to restore Great Salt Lake to 4,200 feet elevation. The lake has lost 73% of its water. Toxic dust storms threaten 2.5M people. How many respiratory illnesses justify water conservation mandates?

Utah Rivers Council drafted the Utah Water Conservation Plan Act (1998). They argue water conservation is essential for Utah's future. But enforcement affects farmers, developers, and residential users. Whose water rights matter most?

Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance advocates for 9+ million acres of protected redrock wilderness through America's Red Rock Wilderness Act (introduced annually since 1989). Rural Utah often opposes this as limiting economic opportunities.

Utah Shooting Sports Council defends Second Amendment rights. Utah has constitutional carry and strong gun culture. They argue armed citizens stop crimes and tyranny. How do we balance rights with safety?

Utah Shooting Sports Council partnered with Intermountain Healthcare on gun locks for suicide prevention. 86% of gun deaths in Utah are suicides. This shows gun rights advocates care about safety too.

Sutherland Institute (founded 1995) advocates for limited government and federalism. They believe state/local control serves citizens better than federal programs. They support school choice, oppose Medicaid expansion, and promote traditional values.

Sutherland Institute publishes annual legislative scorecards rating legislators on conservative principles since 2012. Transparency in government voting helps citizens hold representatives accountable.

Disability Law Center sued over SB199 creating restrictive guardianships. They argue it violates disabled people's autonomy and due process. When should the state override family decisions about disabled adult children?

Disability Law Center enforces Fair Housing Act and ADA protections. They provide free legal services statewide. Businesses sometimes see accessibility requirements as costly mandates. How do we balance access with economic concerns?

Comunidades Unidas (founded 1999) empowers Utah's Latino community. They secured driver privilege cards for undocumented immigrants and in-state tuition for Dreamers. These allow people already here to work legally and contribute. Is this amnesty or pragmatism?

Comunidades Unidas supports pathways to citizenship for undocumented residents. They argue most came as children or overstayed visas (not border crossers) and are integrated community members. But critics say this rewards lawbreaking.

Libertas Institute led occupational licensing reform, removing unnecessary barriers to work. Utah eliminated licenses for hair braiders, florists, and other low-risk occupations. Does this increase opportunity or reduce consumer protection?
Salt Lake Chamber opposes increased business regulation. They argue Utah's pro-business environment creates jobs. But are workers protected? Utah is right-to-work with weak union protections.

Wait But Why's hierarchy: Zealots follow blindly, Sports Fans pick teams, High Mind thinkers question everything. When you see a bill, do you check who supports it before deciding? Or evaluate the policy itself? Are you thinking or cheerleading?

The 2015 Utah Compromise balanced LGBTQ protections with religious liberty. BOTH sides praised it. Equality Utah AND religious conservatives worked together. If Utah can do this on LGBTQ issues, what else is possible through dialogue?

Most Utahns don't know what their legislators vote on. This tracker shows you. But information without action changes nothing. You now see where organizations stand. What will you do with this knowledge?

Libertas (libertarian) supports both gun rights AND criminal justice reform. UEA (progressive) supports both union rights AND higher taxes. Are your positions internally consistent? Or do you just follow your party?
